resources.string: Support for identifying and monitoring your sward species. Click on the menu to start.
Add your notes about this field here…
Are you sure you want to delete this field?
Field not saved because it is empty.
Each species listed is one that was sown. Each bar shows the number of samples out of nine in each survey that was found.

This app is a guide to grassland ley species, featuring identification keys, a sward monitoring tool and information about species\' attributes. It is part of the Toolbox of Multi-species Swards project, funded by the Agri-tech Cornwall and Isles of Scilly Project, led by Duchy College Rural Business School and Rothamsted Research North Wyke. The contribution of farmers, collaborating business partners, and other experts is gratefully acknowledged.

Agri-tech Cornwall & the Isles of Scilly is a £11.8m project to increase Research Development and Innovation in the Agri-tech sector across Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly. Running to June 2021, it is part-funded by the European Regional Development Fund, Cornwall Council and the Council for the Isles of Scilly
The Sward App is designed and built in Cornwall by FoAM Kernow, and released as Free/Open Source Software published under GPL and Creative Commons Licenses.
Which field would you like to survey?
To complete your field survey you need to walk through your field in a \'W\' shape, stopping at 9 points.
At each point, complete a sample survey by recording all the species you can see within a 1m radius of where you are standing.
Surveys can be completed between March and October. If you only have time for one annual survey, this should be done between May and July.
Diagram showing a W shaped path through a field.
You have %d samples to do. Work through the survey until the list is complete.
You have %d sample to do. Work through the survey until the list is complete.
Tap to select the species you can see within 1m of where you are standing.
Enter an email address to send all data on your farm to yourself or someone else."
I consent to sharing my farm data for research
Researchers at Duchy College are interested in your data to understand how multispecies swards perform. Tick this box if you are happy to automatically send them your data for research purposes only.

Information on this form will not be used for any other purpose, apart from research. If you would like your personal data removed in the future, please contact rbs@duchy.ac.uk. Duchy College is part of TCCG. For our privacy notice click here.
Your farm data from the Sward app
Your farm data is attached in a csv spreadsheet, which you can open in excel or open office.
The app was not allowed to write in your storage
Would you like to ID a grass or a legume?
There are five leaflets (2 clasp on the stem)
What is the leaflet on the end like?
The leaflet on the end has no "stalk"
The leaflet on the end has a "stalk"
Are the leaves hairy? Try stroking the underside with your finger.
Leaf is hairless, it feels smooth.
Leaf is hairy, it feels rough.

Is the plant upright, or creeping along the ground? Does it have stolons (horizontal stems with roots along their length)? Try following a flowering stem to the soil with your fingers and gently pull it up.
Plant is creeping. There are roots along the uprooted stem (stolons).
I am not sure (the next question will use less reliable features).
Do the leaves have crescent shaped marks?
If there are flowers, what colour are they?
Look at the place where the leaf joins the stem.
Can you see tiny flaps (called auricles) at the leaf base?
Look closely at the auricles - what can you see?
There are tiny hairs on the auricles
The auricles are short (1mm or less)
The auricles are long (2mm or more)
Cut across the stem - what shape is it?
Look at the place where the leaf joins the stem and find the skin-like flap - this is called the \'ligule\'. What does it look like?
Ligule has a flat, ragged top.
Discover special traits and features of common sward species.
Swipe left and right to see more images.
Click traits for more information, or visit this page to find out more. Please note that ‘thumb symbols’ only compare species of the same group (legume/herb/grass).

No evidence was found, more research is needed.

For the literature up to 2020, 12 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 2 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 3 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 3 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 3 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 4 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 4 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 2 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 8 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, 3 studies partially agreed with score.
For the literature up to 2020, Zinc (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, Copper (3 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, Copper (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, Calcium, magnesium, zinc, copper, sulphur, iron and molybdenum (7 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, Sulphur and calcium (4 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, Potassium, copper and manganese (4 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, Manganese (3 studies).
Likely to exhibit poor tolerance due to taproot.
Unlikely as lacks the relevant chemical compounds.
For the literature up to 2020, tolerant of acidic soil (pH 5.0) (1 study).
For the literature up to 2020, tolerant of acidic soil and low soil phosphorus (3 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, requires pH 6.5 -7.5 (4 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, requires pH > 5 (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, requires alkaline soil (pH 7.0 – 8.0) (3 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, not tolerant of low soil fertility (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, tolerant of low soil fertility (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, not tolerant of low soil fertility (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, not tolerant of low soil fertility (2 studies).
For the literature up to 2020, tolerant of low soil fertility (2 studies).
Plant: Up to 150cm, dark bluish-green, dense tufts (may form clumps)
Stem: Base of stem is flattened (image shows cross-section of stem).
Leaf: Long flat leaves (2–14mm wide) that narrow to a point. Each leaf has a prominent keel (like the keel on a boat)
Stem sheath: No auricles, ligule generally long (2–12mm), ligule has torn, jagged edges.
Plant: Up to 80cm, loose tufts (sometimes forms clumps), variable green
Leaf: The leaf blades are ribbed on the upper side and more glossy on the underside. The leaves clasp the stem by long sheaths
Stem sheath: Short, stubby ligule – barely visible (1mm). Small auricles with no hairs.
Plant: Up to 120cm, whitish-green, erect tufts.
Stem sheath: No auricles, ligule typically short (1–4mm), ligule tatty.
Leaf: The basal (bottom) leaf sheath is often black or brown, the leaves are hairless.
Flower: Tassel-like, cylindrical, up to 13cm long, yellow-green, covered in silver hairs.
Plant: Up to 100cm, dark green and glossy, dense tufts.
Stem sheath: Long auricles clasping the stem. Short ligule (1–2mm) that is hard to see.
Leaf: The underside of the leaf is smooth and glossy, with the top side being slightly rougher, both are hairless. The younger leaves are folded in the sheath before they extend.
Flower: Simple \'florets\' arranged in alternating pattern; no awns (bristle-like hairs).
Plant: Up to 200cm, loose tufts, dark green
Stem sheath: Short ligule (2mm, hard to see). Narrow auricles with fine, wispy hairs.
Leaf: The leaves are long, hairless with rough edges and a characteristic twist or whorl to each leaf. They are rolled in the bud.
Flower: Tassel-like, cylindrical, up to 15cm long, green to grey-purple, no silver hairs.
Plant: Up to 150cm, light grey-green, erect tufts.
Stem sheath: No auricles, ligule up to 6mm long with notched edges and pointed tip.
Leaft: The leaves are long, hairless with rough edges and a characteristic twist or whorl to each leaf. They are rolled in the bud.
Flower: Tassel-like, cylindrical, up to 15cm long, green to grey-purple, no silver hairs.
Plant: Rosette – leaves sprout from base.
Seedling: At 2 weeks – pale, oval leaves.
Leaf: Narrow oval, often hairy, often toothed, often pale green.
Plant: Rosette – leaves sprout from base.
Plant: Rosette – leaves sprout from base.
Seedling: At 2 weeks – first true leaves are pale and toothed.
Leaf: Toothed leaflets arranged in pairs up the stem, dark green with pale underside.
Plant: Rosette – leaves sprout from base.
Flower: Rarely flowers, tiny yellow clusters.
Plant: Rosette – leaves sprout from base.
Leaf: Feathery, dark green, strong smell when rubbed.
Seedling: First true leaf has 5 leaflets
Leaf: 5 leaflets – 3 in a typical ‘clover’ shape and 2 clasping the stem.
Flower: Yellow cluster, often tinged red.
Seedling: At 2 weeks – hairless, with no white marks on leaf.
Leaf: 3 leaflets, hairless, no white crescent marks.
Flower: Pale pink or whitish and later brown, spherical head.
Plant: Upright and has no stolons (rooting stems)
Seedling: At 2 weeks – first true leaf is heart- or kidney-shaped.
Leaf: 3 oval leaflets, top leaflet has short \'stalk\', underside of leaf is hairy.
Flower: White, purple, or yellow clusters.
Seedling: At 2 weeks – hairs on leaf already visible.
Leaf: 3 leaflets, hairy, sometimes white crescent marks. Hairs are most obvious on leaf underside.
Seedling: At 2 weeks – first true leaf has 1–3 long oval leaflets.
Leaf: Multiple oval leaflets arranged in pairs
Flower: Pink with purple veins, cone shaped head.
Seedling: At 2 weeks – white crescent marks already visible.
Leaf: 3 leaflets, hairless, often white crescent marks
Flower: Cream or pinkish-white and later brown, spherical head.
